content.description: Surveys were sent to a random sample of owners of all-wheel-drive (<math alttext="A W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) vehicles and to a random sample of owners of front-wheel-drive (<math alttext="F W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) vehicles. The proportion of owners who were satisfied with their vehicles was recorded for each sample. The sample proportions were used to construct the 95 percent confidence interval for a difference in population proportions (<math alttext="F W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> minus <math alttext="A W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) for satisfied owners. The interval is given as <math alttext="negative 0.01 comma 0.12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>0.01</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0.12</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: A car company believes that the proportion of satisfied owners of <math alttext="A W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles differs from the proportion of satisfied owners of <math alttext="F W D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FWD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles. Does the confidence interval provide evidence that this belief is plausible?

choices.label: No. Most of the values in the interval are not close to 0.
No. The value of 0 is not in the middle of the interval.
Yes. There are more positive values in the interval than negative values.

topic.text: 6.9: Justifying a Claim Based on a Confidence Interval for a Difference Between Population Proportions

skill.text: Skill 4.D: Justify a claim based on a confidence interval.
